Static Web ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: incremental - **Time:** 1990s to 2000s. - **Keywords:** Static, read-only pages. - **e.g.:** HTML pages, directories. - **Limits:** - No interaction: No comments. - Static info: No updates. - Basic look: Minimal visuals. ::: :::: :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![By DALL-E-3](fig/web1.png) ::: :::: ::::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web 2.0 - Social Web ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: incremental - **Time:** 2000s to 2010s. - **Keywords:** Interactive, user content. - **e.g.:** Social media, blogs. - **Limits:** - Privacy risks: Data tracking. - Quality issues: Unreliable content. - Dependency: Users rely on platforms. ::: :::: :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Graph from article on [Evolution of Web](https://dev.to/pragativerma18/evolution-of-web-42eh)](fig/web2.png) ::: :::: ::::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web 3.0 - Semantic Web ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: incremental - **Time:** 2010s onwards. - **Keywords:** Decentralized, AI-driven. - **e.g.:** Cryptocurrencies, Non-fungible token (NFTs), Decentralized applications (DApps). ::: :::: :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![By DALL-E-3](fig/web3.png) ::: :::: ::::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Evolution of Web ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Graph from article on [What is Web 3.0 and why it matters](https://medium.com/fabric-ventures/what-is-web-3-0-why-it-matters-934eb07f3d2b)](fig/evolution-of-the-web.png){width="99%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Future: Web 4.0 ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Graph from article on [Web 4.0 Explained – A Brief!](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/web-40-explained-brief-agiledistrict/)](fig/web4.jpeg){width="80%"} ::: # Web Analytics {data-stack-name="Analytics"} ## Analytics from Web - Understand of the usage of website through measuring & analysing the data generated by its users - A variety of analytics tools speed this process up: - **Google Analytics** - **Commercial:** [Woopra, Mixpanel, Leadfeeder](https://www.leadfeeder.com/blog/google-analytics-alternatives/) - **Open-source:** [Matomo, Open Web Analytics](https://opensource.com/article/18/1/top-5-open-source-analytics-tools) ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![](fig/analytics-tools.PNG){width="45%" height="auto"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ - **Objectives:** - See how your webpage is used. - See who buys something in your store (conversion). - Optimize structure of website, improve on marketing initiatives. ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![](fig/conversion.PNG){width="40%"} ::: --- ### Analytics in Web 1.0 ::: incremental - **Focus:** Basic metrics (views, visits, users) - **Data:** Static content, site structure - **Tools:** Server logs (IP, time, referrer, browser) - **Challenges:** Limited user interaction data, tracking paths - **e.g.:** Click density analysis, HTML analysis for SEO ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Server Logs](fig/server-logs.PNG){width="80%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Analytics in Web 2.0 ::: incremental - **Focus:** User interaction - **Data:** Social media, blogs, comments, sharing (instagram gen) - **Metrics:** Engagement, bounce, conversion - **Challenges:** High data volume, finding valuable insights among noise, privacy concerns - **Tools:** Google Analytics, Adobe Analytics, social listening - **Example:** Clickstream analysis ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Analytics in Web 3.0 ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: incremental - **Focus:** Interoperability, connect everything to web - **Platforms:** Decentralized Apps, smart devices - **Challenges:** Complexity of decentralized data structures, Scalability & integration of AI - **Tools:** Blockchain explorers, AI analysis platforms ::: :::: :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![IoT Devices](fig/smart-lamp.jpg){width="60%"} ![ID](fig/ID.jpg){width="60%"} ::: :::: ::::::: # Web Tracking {data-stack-name="Tracking"} ## Data Collection: Web Tracking ::: callout-note ### Question Think about the last time you browsed online. Did you notice ads related to your recent searches? Ever wonder how that happens? ::: :::: callout-tip ### Scenario ::: incremental - You search for "Shoes" on Amazon. Later, you notice: - Shoe ads on your Facebook feed. - Shoe shops highlighted on Google Maps. - Shoe-related tweets in your Twitter highlights. - *How are these connected? What's the common thread?* ::: :::: ## Track and Recommendation ::: callout-note ### Further Thinking - What implications does this have for privacy and consumer behavior? - How do you feel about this level of personalization? ::: ::: incremental - **Identify** ways you are monitored on the internet. - **Discuss** technologies behind web tracking. ::: ## Web Tracking: Cookies ::: incremental - **Definition:** Small text files stored on your device by websites you visit. - **Info Contained:** Site preferences, login status, tracking indentifiers. - **Structure:** Name, value, attributes (expiration, domain, secure flags) ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![BBC News Cookies](fig/BBCnews.PNG){width="80%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### How Cookies Work? :::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: incremental - You visit a site; it sends a cookie to your device. - Your browser stores the cookie. - Next visit, the browser sends the cookie back. - The site recognizes you and customizes your experience. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Cookie Flow](fig/3rd_cookies.PNG){width="90%"} ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Cookies: Purpose :::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: incremental - **Session Management:** Unique session IDs for restoring states (e.g., cart). - **Personalization:** Remember user settings (e.g., layout, names). - **Tracking:** Monitor inter-page browsing behavior. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Browser Cookies](fig/browser-cookies.jpg){width="80%"} ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Cookies: Types ::: incremental - **Session:** Temporary; deleted when browser closes. - **Persistent:** Stored for a set period. - **Third-Party:** Placed by other domains (ads). - **Supercookies:**, Set at top-level domains (e.g., .com), NO cleared by users, Stored by ISPs (e.g., Virgin, BT). ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Supercookies](fig/BTvsVirgin.jpg){width="30%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Cookies: Privacy ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Essential for functionality but raise privacy concerns. - Tracking cookies can monitor online activity across sites. - Regulations and browser policies are changing cookie use. ::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Privacy Cookies, By DALL-E-3](fig/cookies.png) ::: ::::: ## Web Tracking: Web Logs :::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 75%;"} ::: incremental - Files automatically created and maintained by a server. - Record various activities such as user requests, server responses, errors, and more. - **Steps:** - Customer enters URL. - Request handled by web server. - Server accepts request and logs data. - Server sends response. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Web Logs](fig/weblogs.png) ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Web Logs: Types & Importance ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Types of Web Logs - **Access Logs:** Track all requests to the server. - **Error Logs:** Record server issues and errors. - **Event Logs:** Document user actions (logins, transactions). - Importance in Web Analysis - Understand user behavior and site performance. - Optimize website, troubleshoot issues, and enhance security. - Analyze traffic sources, navigation paths, and interactions. - Privacy Issues - Logs can contain sensitive data. - Secure handling and compliance with privacy laws are essential. ::: ## Web Tracking: Beacons ::::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} ::: incremental - Web Beacons - Also known as pixel tags, tracking pixels, or clear GIFs. - Tiny, transparent images embedded in emails and websites. - Almost invisible to users, usually 1x1 pixel in size. ::: :::: :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} ::: incremental - How Web Beacons Work - When you load an email or webpage, the web beacon is also loaded. - Sends a signal back to the server, indicating the content was viewed. - Can track various user actions like email opens, webpage visits, and ad interactions. ::: :::: ::::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Introduction to Web Beacon {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OWUlWCY4xmE width="100%" height="85%">}} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Usage in Web Analytics :::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 65%;"} ::: incremental - Usage - Used to gather data on user behaviour and engagement. - Helps in understanding content effectiveness and user preferences. - Common in email marketing campaigns to track open rates. - Privacy and Transparency - Raises privacy concerns due to their invisible nature. - Users often unaware they are being tracked. - Importance of ethical use and disclosure in privacy policies. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Web Beacons Usage](fig/web-beacons.png) ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Tracking: JavaScript ``` html ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### JavaScript: Driving Interactivity and Tracking :::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 85%;"} ::: incremental - A powerful programming language used in web development. - Enables dynamic content and interactivity on web pages. - Runs on the user's browser, allowing real-time page updates without reloading. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![TIOBE Index 2024](fig/JS.png){width="95%"} ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### JavaScript in Web Tracking ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 85%;"} - Tracking - Used to track user actions and interactions on websites. - Can capture detailed data like clicks, form submissions, and mouse movements. - Powers sophisticated tracking techniques like event tracking and behavioral analysis. - User Experience - Enhances user experience with interactive features like drop-down menus, modals, and animations. - Facilitates responsive design for optimal viewing across different devices. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### JavaScript: Considerations & Limitations ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Considerations and Best Practices - Balancing functionality with performance: heavy scripts can slow down web pages. - Ensuring compatibility and accessibility across different browsers and devices. - Adhering to privacy standards and user consent, especially in tracking. - Limitations - Not all visitors have JavaScript enabled. - Tags need to be carefully made. - Data collected browser-side, not server-side. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Tracking: Packet Sniffing ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Packet Sniffing: Monitoring Network Traffic - A technique used to capture and analyze packets of data as they are transmitted across a network. - Packet sniffers can intercept data packets and decode their contents. - Stands between the user and the website server. ::: ::: {style="text-align:center; font-size: 55%;"} ![Packet Sniffing Diagram, [from Source](https://www.dnsstuff.com/packet-sniffers)](fig/sniffing.PNG){width="50%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Uses of Packet Sniffing ::: incremental - **Network Analysis:** Identifying network problems, monitoring usage, optimizing performance. - **Security:** Detecting suspicious activities, intrusions, and vulnerabilities. - **Data Collection:** Gathering information transmitted over a network, including web traffic and communications. ::: # Web Design {data-stack-name="Design"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Page Essentials ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 85%;"} - **HTML (HyperText Markup Language):** Standard markup language for creating web pages. - Defines the structure and layout of a web page using a series of elements and tags. ::: ``` {.html style="font-size: 75%;"} Web and Social Network Analytics ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Key Features of HTML ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 65%;"} - Key Features - **Elements and Tags:** Building blocks of HTML, used to create different parts of a web page (like headings, paragraphs, links). - **Attributes:** Provide additional info about elements (e.g., style, class). - Can you spot the table? - **Uniform Resource Locators (URLs):** - Format: `:///` - Common protocols: HTTP, FTP, SIP... - Example: - The file name is inferred as `index.html`. - At that location, the browser will load `index.html`. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Page Essentials: JavaScript ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Example: **Google Analytics** - Collects data on: - Total time a user spends on the site. - Internal links clicked. - Geographical location, OS, browser, screen size, referring site. ::: ``` html ``` # Web Measurement {data-stack-name="Measurement"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## ClickStream ::: {.callout-note} ### What is ClickStream Data? - Tracks the sequence of clicks a user makes while navigating through a website or application. - Provides insights into user behavior and preferences. ::: | **Term** | **Definition** | |------------------------------------|------------------------------------| | **Hit** | Any request for a file from the web server. | | **Page View** | A request to load a single page of a website. | | **Session** | A group of user interactions with your website that take place within a given time frame. | | **Bounce Rate** | The percentage of visitors who navigate away after viewing only one page. | | **Conversion Rate** | The percentage of visitors who take a desired action (e.g., purchase, sign-up). | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Analyzing ClickStream Data ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 80%;"} - Identifying patterns and trends in user navigation and interactions. - Assessing the effectiveness of website design and content strategy. - Enhancing user experience and increasing conversion rates. ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![ClickStream Analysis](fig/clickstream.PNG){width="50%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Clickstream Terminology | **Building Block** | **Definition** | |------------------------------------|------------------------------------| | **Visitor** | Uniquely identified individual causing hits (requests for files, pages, etc.). | | **Visitor Types** | \- Unique Visitor: First-time user.
      - Repeat Visitor: Returns within a given time frame.
      - Returning Visitor: Previously visited.
      - New Visitor: First visit. | | **Metrics** | Single page visit; **Bounce rate (single page)**; **Exit rate (single page)**; page time viewd/duration; **Average page depth**; Click path: the route through the website | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,80]"} ::: {.callout-important style="font-size: 70%;"} $$ \text{Bounce Rate (single page)} = \frac{\text{Number of Single Page Sessions}}{\text{Total Number of Sessions}} $$ $$ \text{Exit Rate (single page)} = \frac{\text{Sessions Ending on Page}}{\text{Total Visits containing that Page}} $$ $$ \text{Average Page Depth} = \frac{\text{Total Number of Pages Viewed}}{\text{Total Visits}} $$ ::: --- ### Example :::{style="font-size: 70%;"} - Calculate the following: a. The **exit rate** of the home page. b. The **bounce rate** of the home page. c. The **conversion rate** (purchase confirmed). d. The **average page depth**. ::: :::{style="font-size: 100%;"} | **Visitor 1** | **Visitor 2** | **Visitor 3** | **Visitor 4** | **Visitor 5** | |---------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------| | Home | Home | Home | Home | Products | | | Products | About | Products | | | | Product 1 | Products | Basket | | | | Basket | Home | Checkout | | | | Checkout | | | | | | Purchase confirmed | | | | ::: --- ### Solution :::{style="font-size: 70%;"} - Calculate the following: a. The **exit rate** of the home page. 2/4 b. The **bounce rate** of the home page.1/4 c. The **conversion rate** (purchase confirmed). 1/5 d. The **average page depth**. 16/5 ::: :::{style="font-size: 100%;"} | **Visitor 1** | **Visitor 2** | **Visitor 3** | **Visitor 4** | **Visitor 5** | |---------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------| | Home | Home | Home | Home | Products | | | Products | About | Products | | | | Product 1 | Products | Basket | | | | Basket | Home | Checkout | | | | Checkout | | | | | | Purchase confirmed | | | | ::: --- ### Bounce Rate ::: {.columns} :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} - Reason - Surfer clicks the back button. - Surfer closes the browser. - Types a new URL. - Does nothing. - Not All High Bounce Rates Are Bad - Purchase confirmation page. - Contact page. - Single-page site (e.g., blog). :::: :::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} Example: My Personal Website ![Contact Me](fig/contactme.PNG){width=100%} :::: ::: --- ## Funnel Analysis ::: {style="font-size: 80%;"} - Funnel Analysis: **Mapping the User Journey** - A method to track and analyze the steps a user takes towards a specific goal or conversion on a website or app. - Helps identify where users drop off and what drives them to convert. - Components of a funnel ::: | **Component** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Entry Point** | Where users begin their journey (e.g., landing page). | | **Intermediate Steps**| Key actions users take towards the goal (e.g., adding items to cart, filling out forms). | | **Conversion** | The final goal or action (e.g., completing a purchase, signing up). | | **Drop-Off Points** | Stages where users exit without converting. | --- ::: {style="font-size: 75%;"} - Optimizing the user experience to increase conversions. - Identifying and addressing barriers in the conversion process. - Tailoring marketing strategies based on funnel insights. ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Funnel Analysis](fig/funnel-analysis.jpg){width=55%} ::: --- ## Customer Journey ::: {style="font-size: 75%;"} - Customer Journey: **Navigating the Path to Conversion** - The complete sequence of experiences customers go through when interacting with your company and brand. - Related to funnel analysis, but more holistic. - Not just a single interaction but a series of touchpoints from initial awareness to post-purchase engagement. - Stages of the Customer Journey ::: | **Stage** | **Description** | |---------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Awareness** | Customer becomes aware of a need and your brand. | | **Consideration** | Customer researches potential solutions and evaluates your offerings. | | **Decision** | Customer decides to purchase your product or service. | | **Retention** | Post-purchase experiences and customer loyalty. | | **Advocacy** | Satisfied customers recommend your brand to others. | --- ::: {style="font-size: 75%;"} - **Importance** - Helps in creating targeted marketing strategies. - Identifies key touchpoints for customer engagement and conversion. - Enhances customer experience and satisfaction. - **Example**: The full experience of the customer with the company, e.g., Successor of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV): ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Customer Lifetime Value](fig/CLV.PNG){width=50%} ::: --- ### Google Analytics ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![](fig/googple-analytics.png){width=80%} ::: --- ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Install with web builder](fig/ga4-cms.png){width=55%} ::: ```{.html style="font-size: 75%;"} ``` ::: {style="text-align:center; font-size: 70%;"} Install manually ::: # Web Future {data-stack-name="Future"} --- ## Heat Maps ::: {.columns} :::: {.column style="font-size: 75%;"} - **Overlay on top of a website:** - The site is divided into pixels. - Colored according to the number of clicks in each area. - **Insights from Heat Maps:** - Complementary to funnel analysis. - Helps answer questions like: - Do users click on advertisements? - Do users find a particular topic more interesting? :::: :::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Heatmap Example](fig/Heatmap-google.jpg){width=100%} :::: ::: --- ## Eye Tracking ::: {.columns} :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} - **Improvement on Heat Maps:** - A device is applied to a person while looking at a screen. - Generates a more precise image of how users scan a website or application. - **Provides Information On:** - Duration of gaze. - Sequence and timing. - Intensity of focus. :::: :::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![[Heatmap Eye Image](https://monetizepros.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/Heatmap-Eye.jpg).](fig/eye_track.png){width=100%} :::: ::: --- ## Tobii Dynavox {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y7_f-pR8SBY&t=88s width="100%" height="85%">}} ## Take Home Messages {data-name="Summary"} ::: {.columns} :::: {.column style="font-size: 60%;"} - **Evolution of Web and Web Analytics** - Web 1.0 and Web Analytics 1.0 - Web 2.0 and Web Analytics 2.0 - Web 3.0 and Web Analytics 3.0 - **Web Tracking Technology** - Cookies - Web Logs - Web Beacons/Bugs - JavaScript - Packet Sniffing :::: :::: {.column style="font-size: 60%;"} - **Web Design Tools** - **HTML** - CSS - JavaScript - **Web Measure Tools** - **Clickstream** - **Funnel Analysis** - Heatmaps - Eye Tracking - ... :::: ::: ## References ::: {#refs style="font-size: 80%;"} :::

**Info Contained:** Site preferences, login status, tracking indentifiers. - **Structure:** Name, value, attributes (expiration, domain, secure flags) ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![BBC News Cookies](fig/BBCnews.PNG){width="80%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### How Cookies Work? :::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: incremental - You visit a site; it sends a cookie to your device. - Your browser stores the cookie. - Next visit, the browser sends the cookie back. - The site recognizes you and customizes your experience. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Cookie Flow](fig/3rd_cookies.PNG){width="90%"} ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Cookies: Purpose :::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: incremental - **Session Management:** Unique session IDs for restoring states (e.g., cart). - **Personalization:** Remember user settings (e.g., layout, names). - **Tracking:** Monitor inter-page browsing behavior. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Browser Cookies](fig/browser-cookies.jpg){width="80%"} ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Cookies: Types ::: incremental - **Session:** Temporary; deleted when browser closes. - **Persistent:** Stored for a set period. - **Third-Party:** Placed by other domains (ads). - **Supercookies:**, Set at top-level domains (e.g., .com), NO cleared by users, Stored by ISPs (e.g., Virgin, BT). ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Supercookies](fig/BTvsVirgin.jpg){width="30%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Cookies: Privacy ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Essential for functionality but raise privacy concerns. - Tracking cookies can monitor online activity across sites. - Regulations and browser policies are changing cookie use. ::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Privacy Cookies, By DALL-E-3](fig/cookies.png) ::: ::::: ## Web Tracking: Web Logs :::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 75%;"} ::: incremental - Files automatically created and maintained by a server. - Record various activities such as user requests, server responses, errors, and more. - **Steps:** - Customer enters URL. - Request handled by web server. - Server accepts request and logs data. - Server sends response. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Web Logs](fig/weblogs.png) ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Web Logs: Types & Importance ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Types of Web Logs - **Access Logs:** Track all requests to the server. - **Error Logs:** Record server issues and errors. - **Event Logs:** Document user actions (logins, transactions). - Importance in Web Analysis - Understand user behavior and site performance. - Optimize website, troubleshoot issues, and enhance security. - Analyze traffic sources, navigation paths, and interactions. - Privacy Issues - Logs can contain sensitive data. - Secure handling and compliance with privacy laws are essential. ::: ## Web Tracking: Beacons ::::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} ::: incremental - Web Beacons - Also known as pixel tags, tracking pixels, or clear GIFs. - Tiny, transparent images embedded in emails and websites. - Almost invisible to users, usually 1x1 pixel in size. ::: :::: :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} ::: incremental - How Web Beacons Work - When you load an email or webpage, the web beacon is also loaded. - Sends a signal back to the server, indicating the content was viewed. - Can track various user actions like email opens, webpage visits, and ad interactions. ::: :::: ::::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Introduction to Web Beacon {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OWUlWCY4xmE width="100%" height="85%">}} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Usage in Web Analytics :::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 65%;"} ::: incremental - Usage - Used to gather data on user behaviour and engagement. - Helps in understanding content effectiveness and user preferences. - Common in email marketing campaigns to track open rates. - Privacy and Transparency - Raises privacy concerns due to their invisible nature. - Users often unaware they are being tracked. - Importance of ethical use and disclosure in privacy policies. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![Web Beacons Usage](fig/web-beacons.png) ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Tracking: JavaScript ``` html ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### JavaScript: Driving Interactivity and Tracking :::::: columns :::: {.column style="font-size: 85%;"} ::: incremental - A powerful programming language used in web development. - Enables dynamic content and interactivity on web pages. - Runs on the user's browser, allowing real-time page updates without reloading. ::: :::: ::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} ![TIOBE Index 2024](fig/JS.png){width="95%"} ::: :::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### JavaScript in Web Tracking ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 85%;"} - Tracking - Used to track user actions and interactions on websites. - Can capture detailed data like clicks, form submissions, and mouse movements. - Powers sophisticated tracking techniques like event tracking and behavioral analysis. - User Experience - Enhances user experience with interactive features like drop-down menus, modals, and animations. - Facilitates responsive design for optimal viewing across different devices. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### JavaScript: Considerations & Limitations ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Considerations and Best Practices - Balancing functionality with performance: heavy scripts can slow down web pages. - Ensuring compatibility and accessibility across different browsers and devices. - Adhering to privacy standards and user consent, especially in tracking. - Limitations - Not all visitors have JavaScript enabled. - Tags need to be carefully made. - Data collected browser-side, not server-side. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Tracking: Packet Sniffing ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 75%;"} - Packet Sniffing: Monitoring Network Traffic - A technique used to capture and analyze packets of data as they are transmitted across a network. - Packet sniffers can intercept data packets and decode their contents. - Stands between the user and the website server. ::: ::: {style="text-align:center; font-size: 55%;"} ![Packet Sniffing Diagram, [from Source](https://www.dnsstuff.com/packet-sniffers)](fig/sniffing.PNG){width="50%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Uses of Packet Sniffing ::: incremental - **Network Analysis:** Identifying network problems, monitoring usage, optimizing performance. - **Security:** Detecting suspicious activities, intrusions, and vulnerabilities. - **Data Collection:** Gathering information transmitted over a network, including web traffic and communications. ::: # Web Design {data-stack-name="Design"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Web Page Essentials ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 85%;"} - - Tracks the sequence of clicks a user makes while navigating through a website or application. - Provides insights into user behavior and preferences. ::: | **Term** | **Definition** | |------------------------------------|------------------------------------| | **Hit** | Any request for a file from the web server. | | **Page View** | A request to load a single page of a website. | | **Session** | A group of user interactions with your website that take place within a given time frame. | | **Bounce Rate** | The percentage of visitors who navigate away after viewing only one page. | | **Conversion Rate** | The percentage of visitors who take a desired action (e.g., purchase, sign-up). | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Analyzing ClickStream Data ::: {.incremental style="font-size: 80%;"} - Identifying patterns and trends in user navigation and interactions. - Assessing the effectiveness of website design and content strategy. - Enhancing user experience and increasing conversion rates. ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![ClickStream Analysis](fig/clickstream.PNG){width="50%"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Clickstream Terminology | **Building Block** | **Definition** | |------------------------------------|------------------------------------| | **Visitor** | Uniquely identified individual causing hits (requests for files, pages, etc.). | | **Visitor Types** | \- Unique Visitor: First-time user.
      - Repeat Visitor: Returns within a given time frame.
      - Returning Visitor: Previously visited.
      - New Visitor: First visit. | | **Metrics** | Single page visit; **Bounce rate (single page)**; **Exit rate (single page)**; page time viewd/duration; **Average page depth**; Click path: the route through the website | : {tbl-colwidths="[20,80]"} ::: {.callout-important style="font-size: 70%;"} $$ \text{Bounce Rate (single page)} = \frac{\text{Number of Single Page Sessions}}{\text{Total Number of Sessions}} $$ $$ \text{Exit Rate (single page)} = \frac{\text{Sessions Ending on Page}}{\text{Total Visits containing that Page}} $$ $$ \text{Average Page Depth} = \frac{\text{Total Number of Pages Viewed}}{\text{Total Visits}} $$ ::: --- ### Example :::{style="font-size: 70%;"} - Calculate the following: a. The **exit rate** of the home page. b. The **bounce rate** of the home page. c. The **conversion rate** (purchase confirmed). d. The **average page depth**. ::: :::{style="font-size: 100%;"} | **Visitor 1** | **Visitor 2** | **Visitor 3** | **Visitor 4** | **Visitor 5** | |---------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------| | Home | Home | Home | Home | Products | | | Products | About | Products | | | | Product 1 | Products | Basket | | | | Basket | Home | Checkout | | | | Checkout | | | | | | Purchase confirmed | | | | ::: --- ### Solution :::{style="font-size: 70%;"} - Calculate the following: a. The **exit rate** of the home page. 2/4 b. The **bounce rate** of the home page.1/4 c. The **conversion rate** (purchase confirmed). 1/5 d. The **average page depth**. 16/5 ::: :::{style="font-size: 100%;"} | **Visitor 1** | **Visitor 2** | **Visitor 3** | **Visitor 4** | **Visitor 5** | |---------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------|---------------------| | Home | Home | Home | Home | Products | | | Products | About | Products | | | | Product 1 | Products | Basket | | | | Basket | Home | Checkout | | | | Checkout | | | | | | Purchase confirmed | | | | ::: --- ### Bounce Rate ::: {.columns} :::: {.column style="font-size: 80%;"} - Reason - Surfer clicks the back button. - Surfer closes the browser. - Types a new URL. - Does nothing. - Not All High Bounce Rates Are Bad - Purchase confirmation page. - Contact page. - Single-page site (e.g., blog). :::: :::: {.column style="text-align:center;"} Example: My Personal Website ![Contact Me](fig/contactme.PNG){width=100%} :::: ::: --- ## Funnel Analysis ::: {style="font-size: 80%;"} - Funnel Analysis: **Mapping the User Journey** - A method to track and analyze the steps a user takes towards a specific goal or conversion on a website or app. - Helps identify where users drop off and what drives them to convert. - Components of a funnel ::: | **Component** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Entry Point** | Where users begin their journey (e.g., landing page). | | **Intermediate Steps**| Key actions users take towards the goal (e.g., adding items to cart, filling out forms). | | **Conversion** | The final goal or action (e.g., completing a purchase, signing up). | | **Drop-Off Points** | Stages where users exit without converting. | --- ::: {style="font-size: 75%;"} - Optimizing the user experience to increase conversions. - Identifying and addressing barriers in the conversion process. - Tailoring marketing strategies based on funnel insights. ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Funnel Analysis](fig/funnel-analysis.jpg){width=55%} ::: --- ## Customer Journey ::: {style="font-size: 75%;"} - Customer Journey: **Navigating the Path to Conversion** - The complete sequence of experiences customers go through when interacting with your company and brand. - Related to funnel analysis, but more holistic. - Not just a single interaction but a series of touchpoints from initial awareness to post-purchase engagement. - Stages of the Customer Journey ::: | **Stage** | **Description** | |---------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Awareness** | Customer becomes aware of a need and your brand. | | **Consideration** | Customer researches potential solutions and evaluates your offerings. | | **Decision** | Customer decides to purchase your product or service. | | **Retention** | Post-purchase experiences and customer loyalty. | | **Advocacy** | Satisfied customers recommend your brand to others. | --- ::: {style="font-size: 75%;"} - **Importance** - Helps in creating targeted marketing strategies. - Identifies key touchpoints for customer engagement and conversion. - Enhances customer experience and satisfaction. - **Example**: The full experience of the customer with the company, e.g., Successor of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV): ::: ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Customer Lifetime Value](fig/CLV.PNG){width=50%} ::: --- ### Google Analytics ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![](fig/googple-analytics.png){width=80%} ::: --- ::: {style="text-align:center;"} ![Install with web builder](fig/ga4-cms.png){width=55%} ::: ```{.html style="font-size: 75%;"} ``` ::: {style="text-align:center; font-size: 70%;"} Install manually ::: # Web Future {data-stack-name="Future"} --- ## Heat Maps ::: {.columns} :::: {.column style="font-size: 75%;"} -
